SINGAPORE NATIONAL
REFERENDUM BILL


    Order read for resumed consideration in Committee.

[Mr SPEAKER in the Chair]



2.33 p.m.

    Clause 27-(cont.)

    The Chairman: We are on clause 27 - an amendment in the name of the Member for Queenstown,

    In page All, line 13, to leave out "declare" and insert "announce the result of the voting in detail electoral division by electoral division before he declares".

    Dr Lee Siew Choh (Queenstown): Mr Speaker, Sir, when the House rose last Friday night, I was explaining why I moved the amendment and that was in order that we might have an honest record of the result of voting. I explained to you, Sir, how the original intention of the referendum immediately after Hong Lim was to test public opinion as to whether or not it still supported the P.A.P. and, what was more important to the P.A.P. Ministers at that time, to allow the P.A.P. to find out the actual strength of the various electoral divisions because, if the result of certain divisions came back showing a heavy majority margin in favour of the P.A.P., those were the seats that would be considered very "safe" seats and those with a not so clear majority margin for the P.A.P.

Column: 426

would be less "safe" seats and those with an uncertain majority margin would be considered third-class "unsafe" seats. Consequent on that, I also mentioned the fact that the original intention of the P.A.P. was to pose one question to the people - namely, "Do you support the P.A.P. or do you support the P.A.P. Government?" and the answer was supposed to come back with a simple yes or no.

    After some time when there was widespread opposition to the sell-out that we had exposed, the P.A.P. switched their original intention and decided to pose two questions to the people instead. I pointed out that that switch occurred before the National Referendum Bill had its First Reading in the House. At that time, Sir, as I have already said, the intention was to have a snap referendum posing two unacceptable questions to the people with complete prohibition of can vassing. But since then, the P.A.P. had realised that the posing of two unaccept able questions to the people would result in a certain reaction and that reac tion would be translated into the return of blank or uncertain votes. And since the P.A.P. did not like the people to know the exact number of those blank votes, it was the intention of the P.A.P. not to let them know how they voted. Therefore, the intention was to hide the shame of the P.A.P. from the eyes of the people. At that stage of my speech, I was tracing the arguments which appear in column 388 of the Official Report of the Select Committee of 16th May, 1962, and I wish to resume from where I left off. I was tracing the arguments that the Ministers gave in defence of not wanting the people to know the truth. If you will remember, Sir, at column 388, the Minister for Home Affairs gave various excuses. First of all, he said:

    '...because the result, according to the proposed Schedule, would be declared division by division whereas, as I think I have said earlier in this Select Committee, the result o the referendum would be declared for Singapore as a whole.'

That was the first excuse, Sir. The second excuse given was that the details of the Form were not in order. Then the

Column: 427

third excuse given was that it was a general Referendum Bill. The fourth excuse given was:

    'The declaration of the result of the poll is an administrative matter, and it is for the Superintendent to compile the statement in the form best suited for a particular referendum.'

The last excuse given by the Minister for Home Affairs was again that it is a general Referendum Bill. I asked whether they accepted the principle that the truth and the result should be clearly presented to the people, and in column 389, the Minister for Home Affairs again said that it is a general Referendum Bill and he gave me the assurance "that whatever form the statement takes, it will be clear and understandable to the people".

    Sir, all these piddling objections were overcome in spite of the Minister for Home Affairs repeating in column 392:

    'Mr Speaker, Sir, I personally think it is impossible. In fact, I consulted my officials on this matter and they advised against it, because no one can anticipate what type of referendum or what kind of question will be posed in future, and it is difficult to design a set Form in the Schedule to this Bill.'

Sir, all these excuses of it being impossible, difficult and unnecessary and leaving the matter to the Superintendent can be summarised in one neat sentence which was used by the Member for Cairnhill, namely, "It allows flexibility for dishonest manoeuvres." In fact, Sir, all these excuses came to nothing. We accepted the legitimate excuse of the details of the statement not being correct. If you will remember, Sir, even you, as Chairman, thought that there was no political undercurrent. I refer you to column 391, Sir, where you said:

    'If that is the only point of difference - I take it there is no political undercurrent in this because if there is any political undercurrent, then I -'

The Minister for Finance then said:

    'I am quite sure that both sides of the House are -'.

Then you said:

    'At one. Can I suggest then that possibly instead of saying "number of ballot papers cast in the affirmative or negative," just say "number of ballot papers cast in respect of each question," and then the Member for Anson's amendment to the amendment to clause 29 will take care of how that is to be worded.'

Column: 428



    Sir, the present amendment which I have moved to this clause embodies all the suggestions made in Select Committee. If the Government were really sincere in those objections appearing in the pages of the Official Report, then they cannot say that they do not want to accept our amendment today. But of course we must always remember that there is in the background this P.A.P. referendum plot - the plot of stealing the votes of the people and calling those votes as "supporting the P.A.P.". Alt this can be revealed in the words of the Minister for Finance. When we pressed for the result to be known, he said in column 393 - somewhere in the middle:

    "...we are absolutely going to give no undertaking on the manner in which the results will be announced.'

Of course, he gave his reasons, but they have all been rebutted.

2.45 p.m.

    Sir, in the present Bill clause 29, sub-clause (2) says:

    'The number of such ballot papers shall be included by the Superintendent in his declaration of the result of the referendum.'

I mentioned that the word "included" was very vague. But, of course, we have learnt since that it was meant to be vague. The fact that I did not know that the actual detailed results would not he announced did not show that we were the only people to have been bluffed. I must mention the Straits Times editorial of 4th June, 1962. The editorial referred to the Referendum Bill. The last sentence of the second paragraph in the third column reads:

    'These "votes" [that is, the blank and uncertain votes] will be declared by the Superintendent of the referendum in a category of their own.'

That shows, Sir, that even the Straits Times editorial writer was confused; the Straits Times editorial writer did not know the intention of the Government really was not to reveal the exact details of the voting of the referendum to the people. Of course, the true intention is as I will now outline.

Column: 429



    I refer you, Sir, to the Plebeian of 8th June, 1962 (that is our official Party Paper), at page 4, col. 6, where I said:

    'To ensure that no one will even know the exact number of blank and uncertain ballot papers, there will be no provision for blank and uncertain votes to be counted separately.'

    The Chairman: Order. I have been following Members who have read extracts from certain documents, and I think a line must be drawn somewhere. If, in fact, this statement which is now being read is the Member's own statement, I do not think he ought to read it from any document. He should now tell the Assembly what his own view is of the whole matter and not something which he has himself written down on paper.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I will, therefore, not quote from the Plebeian, but instead tell you the plot of the P.A.P. which has been exposed by us. Sir, when they talk of declaration of the result of the referendum, there was no intention of letting the people know the exact number of votes that have been cast for the P.A.P. nor the number of votes that are blank, nor the number of votes that are uncertain or other votes. They intend to mix all the blank and uncertain votes from the various divisions, together with the votes supporting the P.A.P. merger proposals and then in the end make one single announcement saying, "So many hundreds of thousands of votes have been cast in favour of the P.A.P. merger proposals." In this way, Sir, even if only 10 per cent of the people really vote for the P.A.P. and 90 per cent cast uncertain votes, the P.A.P. will be able to announce to the world that 100 per cent of voters have voted in favour of the P.A.P.'s merger proposals. Then no one will be able to lodge any objection or complaint of unfairness because of lack of evidence, because nobody will know the true state of affairs and also because nobody will know how many blank votes there actually are.

    This explains why the perfectly legitimate amendment moved by me to introduce a Form in the Schedule for a statement of the results of the referendum was rejected by the Government.

Column: 430

Sir, in any election, there is a statement of the poll after the counting of the ballots. There is such a form - Form Election 17 - in the Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance (Chapter 53). There are similar forms for a statement of the results of the poll in other countries. And any government with nothing to hide need have no fear about publishing the results after counting the ballots. In fact, as I have already indicated, it is the duty of all honest governments to disclose everything there is to disclose to the scrutiny of the people. In this amendment, we merely ask for a statement to show the exact number of votes supporting propositions A, B, C or D; the number of blank votes; the number of uncertain votes; and the number of tendered votes. The people of Singapore have the right to know the true position - good or bad, favourable or otherwise - so that anyone dissatisfied with the results of the referendum can proceed to petition the Referendum Judge against the result of the poll. Now there is provision for referendum petitions, but the true and honest results of the count will be kept secret - conveniently kept secret-so that no one will be able to complain to the Referendum Judge for lack of evidence. And, with this provision - the discovery that came after nights of secret meetings with Machiavelli - the P.A.P. Ministers are now satisfied that the loophole of blank votes is plugged. The arguments put forward by the Ministers in Select Committee only show the Fascist thinking of their whole makeup.

    The Minister for Finance under pressure had to say that he would not be wil ling to reveal the manner in which the results would be announced. When we pressed him further, he said that he would not only not reveal the results of the voting but also reserve the right to disclose or not to disclose the results of the voting. I refer you, Sir, to col. 471 [Official Report of Select Committee of 17th May, 1962], where you said:

    'The point made by the Minister for Finance is that the Government, I think, reserves to itself the right either to disclose or not to disclose the number of uncertain and unmarked votes. That is a fair statement of what the Minister for Finance says. That is all.'

Column: 431

And the Minister for Finance heartily agreed. He said, "Yes". No Government if it calls itself democratic will ever reserve to itself the right to disclose or not to disclose the result of the voting. Only dictators will do that. This is a concrete example of the Fascist streak in our Ministers. And yet the Minister for Health and Law had earlier on said - on the first day, I think - that he wanted to base our Referendum Bill on the general parliamentary Practice of the British system. Which British system ever says that the government reserves its right to disclose or not to disclose? Which British system says that the results of the voting must not be disclosed to the people? Can the Minister quote any precedent? Can he give any example of such a state of affairs? I see that he cannot even answer. He cannot even look up, because -

    The Minister for Health and Law (Mr K. M. Byrne): Who told you that?

    The Chairman: Order. I have already said time and again that Members are addressing the Chair and not Ministers on the Opposite Benches. Whether they are looking down or looking up makes no difference. It is the Chair the Member is addressing.

3.00 p.m.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: This was a shameful state of affairs, Sir. So shameful that even the Member for Cairnhill suddenly woke up. At column 472, in the last two lines, the Member for Cairnhill said:

    "...if it is going to be an embarrassment to the Government, they will not declare. If it is not so, then they will declare.'

And to add to the shameful record, the Minister for Finance said:

    'For the record, there is nothing for the Government to be embarrassed about.'

Of course, they have nothing to be embarrassed about. They are now so thick-skinned that they will do anything. They have no more principles left. The Minister for Finance himself admitted that all these provisions were based on unconstitutional and illegal principles. What else have they got to say?

Column: 432



    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Education (Mr Lee Khoon Choy): If you are not thick-skinned, you should have resigned!

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: All these shameful revelations, Sir, only prove one point. The PA.P. Ministers have always contended that it is the Communists who want to destroy democracy. They call on the Communist bogey and hope to frighten the people of Singapore. But this Bill has proved to the hilt that it is not the Communist bogey that is destroying democracy in Singapore, it is those Fascists who hold power and who do not know how to practise democracy who are destroying the very foundations of democracy in Singapore.

    At the present moment, Sir, there is widespread apprehension in the whole of Singapore. There is already the Council of Joint Action of Opposition Parties both inside and outside the Assembly. The Council of Joint Action have already mapped out a programme of action, but it looks as if the Government may want to put obstacles in the way of the Council of Joint Action. Let them not prevent legitimate and constitutional means of opposition from the people. If the people are denied their peaceful and constitutional means of expression, then all the P.A.P. Ministers as well as the Back Benchers will have to bear full responsibility for their provocative action.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy: What action?

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I do not think I need explain further, Sir, except to give one final quotation to remind the Minister for Home Affairs of what he said on the 14th of March. 1962, during the Second Reading of the Bill. On page 2, at the third paragraph [Vol. 17, No. I col. 68]:

    'With regard to the procedure for the holding of a referendum, the procedure has been largely based and modelled on the provisions of the Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance ...'.

I have moved the amendment, Sir, entirely based and modelled on the Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections Ordinance. Then at the fifth line from

Column: 433

the end of the same paragraph [col. 69]:

    '...the Superintendent shall declare the result of the referendum and in accordance with clause 29 he shall forthwith, after the result has been declared by him, compile a statement of the referendum and shall cause the said statement to be published in the Gazette.'

That statement, Sir, is in the amendment which I have moved in the Schedule. May I quote you again, Sir, on page 3, paragraph 3 [col. 70]? The Minister at that time was talking about amendments moved by the Opposition. He said at the third sentence of the third paragraph on page 3 [col. 70]:

    'Firstly, those amendments which intend ostensibly to ensure propriety in the conduct of the referendum, the Government is prepared to accept.'

I do not think the Minister can ever contest that my amendment is entirely meant to ensure propriety in the conduct of the referendum. Further on, Sir, somewhere in the middle of the same paragraph, he said:

    'However, in order that there can he no doubt about the propriety of the conduct of the referendum, the Government accepts the amendments [of puffing things like polling agents, and allowing polling agents to affix their seals] -'

    The Chairman: Order. I was under the impression that the hon. Member was quoting. I cannot see "puffling" mentioned in the Hansard. I think he ought to quote and then say that they are puffling, if he thinks they are puffling.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: I quote, Sir, somewhere in the middle of the paragraph:

    'However, in order that there can be no doubt about the propriety of the conduct of the referendum, the Government accepts the amendments of the Member for Queenstown...'.

Then he went on to say that he would accept the amendments with regard to polling agents, to allow polling agents to affix their seals. And the final quotation from the Minister for Home Affairs. On page 4 [col. 71], in the first paragraph, somewhere in the lower third paragraph:

    "...the Government has accepted the amendment of the Member for Queenstown so that no one can question the propriety of the referendum.'

Column: 434

Sir, if they do not want to declare the result in detail to the people, then everyone will query the propriety of the referendum. I have already challenged them to produce any precedents where other countries do not let the people know the result of the voting. I do not think they will be able to produce a single one. We have repeatedly said, Sir, that we want an honest, a just and a fair referendum. Let the people know exactly what happens, it looks as if the P.A.P. want to steal the votes of the people and not want the people to know, because they fear the temper of the people against them.

    If only ten per cent of the votes support the P.A.P. and if 90 per cent of the votes are blank or uncertain votes, as a result of two unacceptable questions posed in the referendum, then the P.A.P. hope to declare to the world that a hundred per cent of the people support their merger proposals. 'The only snag is that they just do not want the people to know that they have pinched 90 per cent of the people's votes. That is the dishonesty in the P.A.P. It shows up everywhere.

    For the Back Benches, I would tell them this. If the Front Benches persist in this dishonesty, and the Back Benches abide by this dishonesty and support them in this dishonesty -

    The Chairman: Order. I must stop this intimidation of the Back Benchers. The Back Benchers are there to decide according to their conscience what they should do, and I do not think it is right for any Opposition Member to voice any veiled threats or indicate any veiled intimidation in their speeches.

    Dr Lee Siew Choh: There is no intention to intimidate, Sir. I just want to remind them of their responsibility to the people. That is all. Nothing else, Sir. Anyway, I will close now by saying one thing: that the result of the referendum in detail must be divulged. The Government have a duty to inform the people and the people have a right to know. If the Government want to show that they are responsible in this respect, then there is no reason why they cannot accept the amendment.

Column: 435



    The Chairman: It has been moved as an amendment:

    In page A11, line 13, to leave out "declare" and insert "announce the result of the voting in detail electoral division by electoral division before he declares".

    As indicated the other day, the debate may range over the suggested amendment to clause 30:

    In page A12, line 25, at end, to add "Such statement shall be, as near as may be, in the Form in the Second Schedule to this Ordinance.".

    The debate will then range over the proposed Second Schedule.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the opinion of the Members of this side of the House has already been made known to the people at various meetings, rallies and forums in regard to the matter under debate in this House. What I want to say now is that democracy does not mean that everybody must make a noise.

    We have also heard the arguments from Members of the Opposition, especially the Members of the Barisan Sosialis. It would appear that the argument of every Member is the same. They are just like repeating gramophones, so much so that many people would not even turn to look at the newspapers. That was why I said just now that I would not add too much to that.

3.15 p.m.

    The Member for Queenstown mentioned at the meeting of Parliamentary Secretaries that there was a secret discussion between the Parliamentary Secretaries and the Prime Minister relating to certain safe seats. That is why I avail myself of this opportunity to tell the House something of that. Of course, the Prime Minister used to have an exchange of views with the Ministers and sometimes with the Parliamentary Secretaries. Sometimes we had a cup of tea together and, sometimes, when we were hungry, of course, we would take some food. But these occasions were termed by those turncoats now in the Barisan Sosialis as certain secret dealings. That is a most shameful way of saying things.

Column: 436



    We can all remember that during the Hong Lim by-election those so-called heroes opposite us were all P.A.P. Members. They used to say that they were 100 per cent loyal to the P.A.P. They also said that the P.A.P. was a 100 per cent good and honest Government. In the Hong Lim by-election, the question we were faced with was whether we should resign because at that time many sections of the people were of the opinion that the P.A.P. should resign. But certain other sections of the people were of the opinion that we should not resign. The Prime Minister then consulted the opinions of all the Parliamentary Secretaries. You all remember that at that time there was no such concept as Malaysia. At that time, the P.A.P. leadership was of the opinion that there was only a meagre hope of merger. We did not see much possibility of having a merger and we thought that if we were to continue to govern, it would be difficult for us to justify ourselves to the people. Everybody understood that. Certain of those people who are now opposite did not want to resign. I myself also did not know why certain Parliamentary Secretaries did not want to resign at that time. We also discussed at that time certain things, but they were not relevant to the holding of the national referendum, because Tunku Abdul Rahman only mentioned the Malaysia concept at the foreign correspondents' luncheon. The Parliament gave support in principle.

    During the Hong Lim by-election, we disclosed officially our principles relating to merger, education and labour. But the holding of a national referendum was something that originated later on, and, therefore, it was wrong to say that we were trying to make use of this national referendum for our own purposes. The impression I got from the meeting was that it was a secret meeting of Parliamentary Secretaries and the Prime Minister. It was held at the Prime Minister's Office. I also attended the meeting. The atmosphere was that certain Parliamentary Secretaries, especially the Member for Queenstown, were of the opinion that if the Prime Minister resigned, then the

Column: 437

Parliamentary Secretaries should take over the reins of government. I was shocked to hear that. The leaders of our Party -

    The Chairman: Order. I do not know how this is relevant to the amendment. The Parliamentary Secretary has made his point. He has answered the allegation that there was talk about a referendum being held to gain safe seats. I think he has answered that point. Now he is going into details which will open out a debate which is completely irrelevant.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not prepared to go into details to disclose the details of that meeting. What I want to say is that at that time there was already a plot underway to take over the reins of government. Therefore, the Member for Queenstown mentioned that we had a meeting for the purpose of finding out safe seats for the Ministers and to say that this had something to do with the holding of the national referendum. But I will rebut it as nonsense. If what he had said was true, then why from the Anson by-election up to now did he never mention it? Mr Speaker, Sir, the result of this national referendum is based on one or two questions posed to the people and is, of course, different from a general election. Because during a general election the people may want to elect individuals and may not elect a Party. Because, perhaps, some political Parties may be strong, then people in certain constituencies may want to vote such political Parties. But others may want to vote individuals. That is why we cannot mix these two issues together. We cannot mix a national referendum with a general election together. That is why the general result of a national referendum can reflect generally the views of the general populace. On this I would add that the Barisan Sosialis have been in the habit of accusing us of not willing to let the people have a chance of freedom, i.e., to express their opinions and views. We should know that everybody here, including everyone outside, and all political Parties have agreed that we should

Column: 438

have a merger. Now, if we ask only one question, whether they want the White Paper merger, then, according to the Barisan, they will say no; then it will mean there will be no merger. That is why -

    The Chairman: Order. The hon. Member has gone away from the amendment. The amendment merely seeks to suggest that the Superintendent should make a declaration of the result of the referendum in detail electoral division by electoral division. We have completed the debate on whether there should be a yes or no.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I mentioned that I wanted only to add something more. I did not intend to carry on with details. The Member for Queenstown a little while ago said I mentioned a certain so-called Tripartite Joint Action Council. We never thought the Barisan could have been of such stuff without a stand of its own. Because during the Hong Lim by-election, Mr Ong Eng Guan also criticised that the Liberal Socialists were a pro-Western, capitalist and colonialist Party. But today, for the purpose of making use of a political Party, they do not care whether a Party is pro-capitalist or pro-colonialist. They now want to co-operate with such political Parties. All those who have read stories relating to Hitler and Fascists in Germany can understand what is meant by Fascism, it is strange that the words and phrases used and the meanings in relation to those phrases could only be found in their dictionaries. If we were Fascists, I believe the Member for Queenstown and the representatives of the Barisan Sosialis would not be so free nowadays to hold rallies and conduct meetings and shout here and there. Perhaps they might have vanished without a trace. If they want to talk about democracy and if they want to show that they really want to preserve and uphold parliamentary democracy, I believe they will not have given aid secretly to students to prevent other students from going into the examination centres to sit for their examination, if that is their kind of democracy -

Column: 439



    The Chairman: Now, that is irrelevant. Let us come back to the amendment.

    Mr Lee Khoon Choy(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, I was just mentioning those points in passing in order to re fute their accusation that we are dictatorial. To sum up, I am of the opinion that the Member for Queenstown is trying to avail himself of this opportunity in this House to create trouble and to accuse us of using this national referendum to prepare to secure safe seats for Ministers. All this talk from him is nonsense.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, quite frankly I do not understand this amendment. If I may read it. It says:

    'to leave out "declare" and insert "announce the result of the voting in detail electoral division by electoral division before he declares".'

3.30 p.m.

    Now the general effect is that if the amendment is carried, you get this position. There are 51 electoral divisions in Singapore. One could reach this position - 26 divisions in favour of the proposition, 25 divisions against the proposition, and yet the votes cast in favour of the proposition in 26 divisions could be less than those cast in the 25 divisions. And vice versa it could hap pen the other way, Mr Speaker. So that you could get the position where 26 divisions favour, from a division point of view, the proposition; yet the number of votes cast in those 26 divisions could be very much less; and the votes cast in the 25 divisions could be very much more.
